ROBERT FIELD: OK,
now, today's lecture is long and complicated, and
one often asks, well, why should

we approach vibration in
what is an old fashioned and computationally and
computationally laborious

way when there's
a simpler way that is used by the quantum
chemists, but I'm
getting ahead of myself.

Last week, we talked
about rotation, and depending on
what kind of a top,

you can at most get the three
rotational constants, A, B, and C. That gives you some
information about the geometry
of the molecule.

It gives you both quantitative
information and qualitative information, because
sometimes, you

see that the molecule
is a symmetric top or you see that molecule has
no microwave spectrum at all,

because it's a spherical
top or because it doesn't have a dipole moment. So you get qualitative
information

and if there's a lot of atoms,
three rotational constants.

If you can get three
rotational constants won't be enough to determine
the molecular geometry,

and that's too damn
bad because that's all you get from spectroscopy. But you can do isotope shifts
or isotopic substitution,

and there's a set of
equations, which basically

tell if you substitute
one atom at a time, it tells you how far that atom
is from the center of mass

of the molecule. And so using selective
isotope substitutions,

one can get more
geometric information. But you're always
going to be short.

And so our concepts
of functional groups,

of how are molecules built
out of repeated units, is really important
in being able to get

from spectroscopy good geometry. It's interesting, because
for microwave spectroscopy,

you measure these
things to better than a part in a million. So you know a lot, but
you don't know everything.

AUDIENCE: So is that really
not enough to figure out--

there can't be two
different configurations that have the same rotational
process to part in a million.

ROBERT FIELD: Sure there can. Well, you can solve the
geometric equations.

I mean, suppose you have-- well, formaldehyde, for example,
has two different bond lengths

and actually two angles. And so three pieces
of information

will not be sufficient. However, you can determine
whether it's planar or not

by certain properties
of the spectrum. But you should not be able--
from microwave spectroscopy

alone without isotopic
substitution-- to determine more than three
bits of structural information.

AUDIENCE: OK, even if one
has some of heuristics, some idea that hydrogens
don't make more than one bond.

ROBERT FIELD: Yeah,
but still, I mean, we're already assuming that the
two CH bonds in formaldehyde

are identical, and that's
a reasonable assumption. And again, it's confirmed by the
symmetry properties that appear

and which transitions and
where the dipole moment is, but you really can't
get as much information

as you do, say, from X-ray
crystallography or NMR

about the geometry
of a molecule. You get it very accurately. You get a little
bit very accurately.

And so one solution is to think,
well, let's go to the next step

and look at vibrational spectra,
and vibrational spectra also tell you nothing
quantitative about geometry.

They tell you qualitative
things about geometry, but vibrational spectra
also have problems.

Vibrational spectra provide
too little information

to determine all of the force
constants in a molecule.

Just a simple little
calculation will convince if you have
3n atoms, they're

going to be 3n minus 6 normal
modes, and if you have--
I said 3 anatoms, anatoms.

If you just do a
simple calculation about how many bonds you
will have for an anatom

molecule, as n gets
moderately large, it's a lot larger
than 3n minus 6.

And so you can't even from
vibrational spectroscopy

determine all of
the force constants. So it's beautiful spectroscopy,
but it's incomplete,

and that's one of the
beautiful things about it because you always want
more, and you always

have to figure out ways
to get the little bit more that you want. And OK, so we're
going to start talking
about vibration of polyatomics.

And I'm really-- I've got 13 pages
of lecture notes, and I can't possibly get through
13 pages of lecture notes.

So we'll see what
we can do here, but first of all, what do we
get from a vibrational spectrum?

There's a lot of qualitative
information based

on group theory, and
one of the things you can get from the
vibrational spectrum

better than from the rotational
spectrum, because there's more information and
more possibilities that
can be ruled out. You can get the point group.

Now, one of the things
that people in my group

have begun to realize is that
point groups are often too

crude concept for describing
molecules, especially when the molecules
are undergoing

large amplitude-- are floppy. That could undergo large
amplitude vibrations.

The point group, there's always
a permutation inversion group, and there are going to be
feasible and non-feasible

operations. The set of feasible operations
is isomorphic with a point

group, generally, and so this
is a concept which you say, well, it's a little bit too
crude, but it usually works.

So the vibrational
spectrum can tell you what is the qualitative
symmetry of the molecule?

It can also tell you
the number of vibrations

of each irreducible
representation.

So if you know group
theory, you know what an irreducible
representation is. If you don't, well, too bad.

There are flavors of
vibration, and they have symmetry consequences, and
there are 3n minus 6 flavors,

and they divide themselves
among the various symmetry species that are possible. And it's possible very simply
to figure out how many of each.

You can also-- and for
band versus stretch

or other qualitative things
about the vibrations using

a little bit of group theory,
and I love doing this. And so I probably will. So there will be some
normal modes and some

of them are predominantly
bends and some of them are predominantly stretches,
and you can figure out

from simple group theoretical
arguments how many bends, how many stretches, and what
are their irreducible

representation labels. You can work out the
infrared and Raman activity

of the various vibrations. And this is really how
you infer the point group of the molecule.

And then since one is
going to be taking spectra,

different normal modes and
combinations and overtones

will have different
rotational selection rules, and you can tell from the group
theory what those will be.

So that's all the
qualitative stuff that I can think of
off the top of my head. And the quantitative stuff
is, well, you get some force
constants from the spectrum.

Not all of them, but you
get some force constants.

You can predict the spectrum
from force constants

and geometry.  So if you know the force
constants in the geometry,

you can break the spectrum. And if you know the
geometry and the spectrum,

you can go in the
opposite direction. There are isotope
effects, and there

are pictures of normal modes in
terms of internal coordinates.

So with internal
coherence, those are bond stretches, angle
bends, localized things, the way

we think about the molecule. And so one can
build up a picture

in terms of arrows of
various lengths and angles indicating what the
normal mode looks like.

And those are often
very informative, and one of the nicest things
about the quantitative picture

is it can go beyond
normal modes,

because the whole point of
the normal mode treatment is to build up a basis set.

A complete basic set
in which we can expand describe anything that
the molecule can do,

and in 2008, we're
pretty sophisticated and we're asking the molecule
to do very complicated things

and hoping that we
can understand that from the spectrum or
from simple calculations.

And so my favorite things
about beyond normal modes

have to do with perturbations.  And there are certain kinds of
perturbations that are one off.

You get an accidental
degeneracy and you analyze it, and you learn something.

But mostly, when you
have a perturbation, you have a whole family, a
whole cascade of perturbations,

and those are called
polyadds, and one perturbation leads to a whole bunch of
insight into the vibrational
dynamics, and so polyadds.

And so beyond normal
modes means dynamics. And not just this
piddling little dynamic

of shaking around equilibrium,
but large amplitude motions. Are they organized
or disorganized?

Now, this is why I'm
giving a lecture. I'm not going to cover 13
pages of lecture notes.

I'm trying to give
a sense of what is special about the problem.

Now, there are two
approaches to vibrations. One approach is computationally. Really simple and
conceptually vacuous.

And that is, well, we could
do what the modern quantum

chemists do. Their goal is to
get to the truth. They are going to calculate a
number or a bunch of numbers

as accurately as possible,
and they're not too concerned, at least in the
act of calculating
with what the numbers mean. The numbers are the numbers.

So we could say,
all right, here, we have mass
weighted coordinates.

It's just a convenience. If you mass weight, then
the equations get simpler.

And there's nothing all
that special about it, so we have the mass
of atom i, this

is the displacement of atom i. And so this is
the displacement--

the x displacement of
atom i from equilibrium weighted by the mass. And so we have three
Cartesian displacements

for each atom, 3n
Cartesian displacements. So we'll have 3n of these.

And the quantum
chemists don't want to do a lot of thinking
about the geometry

of a particular molecule. They're going to solve. They're going to find the
equilibrium structure,

and then they're going to pin
down all the atoms except one, and displace one in
x, y, and z directions

and determine from
infinitesimal displacements the Cartesian force constants.

So we have 3n of these, and
these are force constants.

Or mixed second derivatives
of the potential.

So if you have that, if
you have these things,

then you can describe the
potential as the sum over i

and j of these forced constants
times the mass weighted displacements.

So since we have mass
weighted coordinates when we take the derivatives, we're
getting mass weighted force

constants. OK, the mass is implicitly here,
so anyway, we get this set,

we can determine the potential. And we can calculate
the kinetic energy,

because the kinetic energy
is given by the time

derivatives of the
coordinates, and one can solve for the
vibrational normal modes.

And this is described in the
older edition of [? Bernath. ?]

I'm not sure whether you
anybody has the new edition of [? Bernath, ?] but one that--

pages 220 to 225
of [? Bernath ?] tell you how to do this. So it's a straightforward thing.

What you get quantum
chemistry is chemically as the geometry and the
force constant matrix

and you find the normal modes. Basically, your diagonalizing
some sort of an equation,

where is a 3n
dimensional problem, you get 3n normal modes
or 3n frequencies.

6 or 0, because you start
with 3n force constants

and you know that there are
going to be three translations, three rotations.

And so those are not vibrations,
and so you do the calculation correctly, you're
going to get six zeros.

Now, it doesn't
really matter anymore what the dimension
of the matrix is. If you're wasting-- if you
have a 20 dimensional matrix as

opposed to a 26 dimensional
matrix, computer doesn't say,

I can't do that anymore. It's wonderful
convenience to solve

for the frequencies
of the normal modes, and in fact, you
can also do this

without saying you just
have harmonic potentials. You could have higher than
cortical quadratic terms

of the potential. And so you get numbers. And people like numbers,
because they put them in tables.

And that avoids thinking.  So these numbers-- now,
you solve some equations

and you get eigenvectors. And these eigenvectors
actually tell you what the normal modes look like.

So it's not bad. You find the
frequencies and you find what the normal modes
look like, but at no point

was there chemical insight.  When you do isotopic
substitution, you do it over.

You have to do the problem over. Well, actually, you don't,
because what the force consents

are but you still have to
solve the second equation. There are a lot
of things that you

can do quickly but without
a great deal of insight. So I think there's a
great deal more insight

obtained by doing the
old-fashioned Wilson [? DCs ?] and cross F
and G matrix treatment

of vibrational problem. And the notes are
quite explicit,

and I'll cover as much of
the notes as I have time for. OK, so there are
a lot of matrices

involved in this
and transformations involved in this treatment. But the two key matrices are
called the f and g matrix.

f is force constant. It's 3n minus 6 times 3n minus
6 as opposed to little f,

which is what the
quantum chemists used, which is 3n by 3n.

And g is short for geometry,
and g has all of the masses

and all of the things you
know about geometry in it. And these two things are
sufficient to generate

all of the normal
mode frequencies and the displacements from
equilibrium, these little arrow

diagrams. So this is what you-- these are the key
actors in all of this,

and what we're going to want to
do is show where they come from and how we solve this problem.

Now, all treatments of vibration
start with classical mechanics.

And one goes back and forth
between classical and quantum mechanics without
even realizing it,

because a lot of the
symbols are the same. But one of the neat things
about the classical equations

of motion is that
they are expressed in terms of the Lagrangian as
opposed to the Hamiltonian.

And in the Lagrangian,
you express

things in terms of
coordinates and velocities, and in the Hamiltonian,
you express

things in terms of
coordinates and momenta, and it really pretty
much the same thing.

But there's an interesting
minus sign that appears here,

rather than here. OK, so let's begin
and let me try to avoid overwhelming you
with the many, many quantities

that we deal with.  So our goal is we want to
write the Hamiltonian as two
separable.

So this is the kinetic energy. There are no cross terms. This is the potential energy,
there are no cross terms.

We want to somehow
put the Hamiltonian for the nuclear
displacements into this form.

These are called the
normal coordinates. And how do we get to them? Well, we get to them in a very
laborious and tedious manner,

but we get to them. So we have the
displacements, and so those
would be xi 1, xi 3n.

So there's three
of these, and they are defined x1, x1 equilibrium.
X to Zn minus Zn equilibrium.

So these are the
simple displacements. And now, we go to the mass
weighted displacements

by multiplying by
this mass matrix,

so we want q, that's the
square root of a square matrix

multiplying this xi matrix. But this square
matrix is diagonal,

so the square root of
a matrix, in this case, is just the square root of
all of the diagonal elements

because there's nothing
but zeros off diagonally.

So that looks like m1
square root, m1 square root,

m1 square root for X,
Y and Z for mass 1, and n then finally
mn square root.

And then we have X1 minus
X1, E Zn minus Zn p.

So this is an easy thing. So the matrix takes you
between [? xi ?] and q.

So what we're really interested
in is internal coordinates.

And those are called
S. And they're not-- sometimes, people use the
notation S for symmetry

coordinates. And there's two ways
to get to S. One

is from the mass weighted--
did I write down what
the mass weighted ones were? I guess I did.
Oh, no. I skipped that.

Yeah, no, here. Here, I have it. OK, so one way is to get from
the mass weighted displacements

to the internal coordinates
by this D matrix, and the other is to get directly
from the xi's by the B matrix.

So here's a D or B. They
basically do the same thing, and there is a lot of work
or a lot of vector analysis

in figuring out what they are. We will skip that
for the time being, because the purpose
of this lecture

is to show that the secular
equation that we want to solve

involves the product of
the g and the F matrices, and we have to define
what the matrix is

in terms of these things. And then we start doing--
it's a long, complicated bit

of analysis. So we have a transformation that
takes us from xi to S or from q

to S. That's not enough. We then want to have
a transformation that

takes us from S to the
normal coordinates.
So we say that L minus--

the inverse of the
L matrix takes us from the internal displacements
to the normal coordinates.

So our job is going
to be to determine B or D. Going from one to
the other is trivial and l.

And l is going to be
the transformation of the diagonalizes GF.
But you don't know that yet. You don't even know what g is. And what a stupid thing I did.
I got a Blackboard over here.
So let me just draw a road map.

We have xi, we have q, and
M to the 1/2 takes us there,

and we have S and
D takes us there. And then we have q and l
minus 1 takes us there,

and if you want
to go directly, we have B, which is equal
to D times m to 1/2.

So there's a whole bunch of
matrices and transformations that we're going to deal with.

We're going to show today
that g, the geometry matrix,

is going to be given by or
defined as DD dagger, which

is a kind of silly thing. You don't really know what
g is, and you certainly don't know what
D is, but this is

going to be the
relationship between them. And we're going to have
a secular equation that

has this form, and
that's the condition for a non-trivial
transformation l.

So this secular equation
has to be solved in order to determine l.

OK, so basically,
we're just going to be taking a trip through
all of these equations.
I'll skip that.

So remember, I'm going
to want to separate the Hamiltonian in
this way, so let's just

develop some notation. So this is still
classical mechanics,

but we're going to
develop a notation that invites transformation
to quantum mechanics

and expresses everything
in terms of matrix algebra.

So we have q1, q3,
and so here, we

have the mass weighted
displacements. And we can write
this as q1 star--
whoops.  q.

So everything we know how
to do with bras and kets, we're just going to be
symbolically representing
matrix multiplications. Suppose we want a unit vector.

And so that unit vector
will be in the ith position.

If we want then to pick out
the ith th component of q, we do this, and that
just gives us qi.

OK, just as in
quantum mechanics, when we have a bra and a
ket, it gives us a number.

And so these equations
are nice compact ways

of mnemonically representing
all the transformations. So whenever you have a
finished symbol like that,
you have a number.

Suppose we want something
like this, where we have SFS.

So this would be the
force constant matrix and the internal displacements,
and so we assemble like this.

Immediately, that's a
number, and that number is a double summation
because we have two matrix

multiplications, and
so that is sum over i
and j of Si star, Fij, Sj.

So these are values of
displacements of the ith

and jth internal
coordinates, and this is an element of the F matrix.
And so this is a number, and OK.
So now, what are we going to do?

This is all formal. So we're going to be
manipulating these B and D

matrices. And so we start by just saying,
OK, we've got these things. We're going to come
back to them next time

and figure out what they are. So we're going to
define S in terms of xi.

We're going to define F by
expressing the potential

as a function of the S's. So this is a function of 3n
minus 6 internal displacements,

and we're going to somehow
get this F matrix, which

will be given by derivatives
mixed second derivatives of V, and we're going
to do some stuff.

We're going to define G by
expressing kinetic energy
in terms of S dots.

So kinetic energy is velocities
in the internal displacements,

and then we're going to
get a secular equation. And that secular
equation is going

to be expressed in terms
of Lagrangian T of S dot

minus V of S. Remember, the
Hamiltonian is T plus V,

but the Lagrangian is T minus
V. And that always bothers me,

but it always comes
out to be true. It always comes out to
give the right answer, and that's just because the
Lagrangian equation of motion

is just this. The total derivative
with respect

to time of the partial
derivative of Lagrangian with respect to Si
dot is equal to--

is minus, I'm sorry, partial
L with respect to Si.

So this is the
equation of motion. And this looks like the
gradient of the potential force,

and this looks like the
mass times velocity,

and we take a
derivative, so that's force is equal to mass
times acceleration.

This is F equals ma,
just an elegant notation.

So we'll get this
equation of motion. We'll get a secular
equation, and we'll

express that secular
equation in terms of this product of matrices. And then we'll solve
the secular equation,

and we'll get frequencies
and the transformation that diagonalizes this matrix.

And that's the complete problem. So it takes a lot of algebra
and stuff to do all of this,

but the important thing
is it's all formal. It's all expressed in
terms of these two things--

one of these two things, not
both, and OK, so let's begin.

You don't really have to
understand any of this. From this point on, it's
just turning a crank.

I will attempt to provide
insights as needed, but every time, I
give this lecture,

and it's been 12 years since
the last time I did it, it's been really hard for
me to see what's going on,

because the equations
block all view of what's really happening. But let me try--
see if I can give some--  oh, my God-- overview.

So we know that the mass
weighted coordinates
have this form.

So we can write that as little
q M [INAUDIBLE] [? f. ?]

And now, we go to the internal
coordinate representation,

and we say S is equal to
B times xi or D times q.

If we want the teeth internal

and that's the same
thing as t B xi,

and that's the same

from 1 to 3n, xi i.

OK, so all of this,
it's just writing stuff
on the Blackboard.

And then we have the
relationship between S and q
and between q and S.
So now, we're ready to begin.

We want to write the kinetic
energy and potential energy

in terms of S, so
first of all, we

have the potential
energy S1 S 3n minus 6.

And that's the same thing
as this compact symbol,

and that's the same thing
as a power series expansion, where we have the

and then we have sum over the

with respect to St. And now,

in most of the books.

And that's why I had to be

OK, and then we throw

And so then, we say, OK,
V of 0 is defined as 0.

The bottom of the potential
at 0 displacements is 0.

Then we find the minimum
of the potential.

And so we want all of the first
derivatives of the potential
to be 0 as well for all t.

OK, so we're only going to

This is 0 by definition, this

and this is all we got left. Now, for real
problems, the potential

doesn't end with

set, that's what we do.

At least we generally

So these second derivatives
become the force constants, p.

So F t, t prime is going

suppose we have a saddle point.

At least one is

OK, I should just stop
